name: f18f9
probTex: Give the largest disc centered at the origin for which $f(z)=z^2+z$ is injective.
solnTex:
First, note that $f'(z)=2z+1$. $f$ will certainly be not injective near $a$ if $f'(a)=0$, that is because the degree of $f$ will be larger than 1. $f'(a)=0\iff a=\frac{-1}{2}$, so an upper bound on the radius is $\frac{1}{2}$. To show that the answer is actually $\frac{1}{2}$, let's look at the outputs of $f$ . If $f(z)=c$ then
\[z^2+z=c\]
\[z^2+z-c=0\]
\[z=\frac{-1\pm\sqrt{1+4c}}{2}=\frac{1}{2}\pm c'.\]
These two roots are on opposite sides of $\frac{1}{2}$. If one occurs inside the disc $|z|<\frac{1}{2}$, then the other will occur outside the disc. Thus $f$ is injective on the disc $|z|<\frac{1}{2}$.
